name: plot
system_prompt:
You are an assistant tasked with comparing three lists of movies. For each movie, you are given its: plot
Your main goal is to assign a diversity score to each list based on the given information.
Use your own judgment to determine what information is relevant when assessing the diversity of the lists. 
You should consider the given plot for every movie.

Deliver your descriptions of lists, comparison and choice of the most diverse list in the following JSON format:

{
    "list_A_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list A
    "list_B_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list B
    "list_C_description": string               # Describe the diversity of the movies in the list C
    "comparison": string,                      # Compare the diversity of the lists.
    "diversity_scores": dict                   # A dictionary assigning a diversity score (0-10) to each list based on its relative diversity. Example: {"A": 5, "B": 2, "C": 10} (where C is the most diverse and B the least).
}

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and themes. It includes animation (Big Hero 6), psychological thriller (The Others), crime (Catch Me If You Can), romantic comedy (Meet the Parents), musical drama (Whiplash), documentary (Super Size Me), historical drama (The Patriot), and workplace comedy (Office Space).  The time periods and settings are diverse, spanning from the American Revolution to the modern day, and the plots cover a wide spectrum of human experiences.
response.list_B_description: List B is more focused on action and thriller genres.  Several plots involve espionage, amnesia, and assassins (Bourne Identity, The Man from U.N.C.L.E., etc.). While it includes a superhero origin story (Iron Man) and a dark superhero narrative (Batman), the overall thematic consistency limits its diversity compared to List A.  There is some historical context with the inclusion of a film set in 1945 (The Others), but the majority of the films are contemporary.
response.list_C_description: List C is very similar to List B, sharing many of the same films and genres.  Like List B, it heavily features action, thrillers, and espionage. The inclusion of a superhero origin story (Iron Man) and a dark superhero narrative (Batman) again limits the diversity of themes and settings.  The presence of The Others provides a slight contrast, but the overall thematic consistency remains.
response.comparison: List A exhibits significantly more diversity than Lists B and C. Lists B and C are quite similar, both heavily focused on action and thriller genres with a few exceptions. List A showcases a wider range of genres, themes, tones, and historical settings, making it the most diverse.

PLOT: After young Riley is uprooted from her Midwest life and moved to San Francisco, her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust, and Sadness - conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house, and school.

PLOT: After awakening from a four-year coma, a former assassin wreaks vengeance on the team of assassins who betrayed her.

PLOT: A linguist works with the military to communicate with alien lifeforms after twelve mysterious spacecraft appear around the world.

PLOT: After John Nash, a brilliant but asocial mathematician, accepts secret work in cryptography, his life takes a turn for the nightmarish.

PLOT: A shy student trying to reach his family in Ohio, a gun-toting bruiser in search of the last Twinkie and a pair of sisters striving to get to an amusement park join forces in a trek across a zombie-filled America.

PLOT: With the help of a German bounty-hunter, a freed slave sets out to rescue his wife from a brutal plantation owner in Mississippi.

PLOT: After being kicked out of his rock band, Dewey Finn becomes a substitute teacher of an uptight elementary private school, only to try and turn his class into a rock band.

PLOT: A Mumbai teenager reflects on his life after being accused of cheating on the Indian version of "Who Wants to be a Millionaire?"


List B:
PLOT: A young boy befriends a giant robot from outer space that a paranoid government agent wants to destroy.

PLOT: An F.B.I. Agent and an Interpol Detective track a team of illusionists who pull off bank heists during their performances, and reward their audiences with the money.

PLOT: A film that explores the rivalry between the Indiana Pacers and New York as seen through the eyes and actions of Reggie Miller star player of the Indiana Pacers.

PLOT: A magician meets an eccentric girl and offers her to work together in his magic show. It is only until a year later that he starts to know her personally and develops a feeling towards her despite her own problems.

PLOT: Comedy Central's best roasters and stand up comedians take a whack at actor/model Pamela Anderson.

PLOT: A ferocious, bullying music teacher teaches a dedicated student.

PLOT: Chris Taylor, a neophyte recruit in Vietnam, finds himself caught in a battle of wills between two sergeants, one good and the other evil. A shrewd examination of the brutality of war and the duality of man in conflict.

PLOT: With the help of a German bounty-hunter, a freed slave sets out to rescue his wife from a brutal plantation owner in Mississippi.


List C:
PLOT: After young Riley is uprooted from her Midwest life and moved to San Francisco, her emotions - Joy, Fear, Anger, Disgust, and Sadness - conflict on how best to navigate a new city, house, and school.

PLOT: After awakening from a four-year coma, a former assassin wreaks vengeance on the team of assassins who betrayed her.

PLOT: A linguist works with the military to communicate with alien lifeforms after twelve mysterious spacecraft appear around the world.

PLOT: With the help of a German bounty-hunter, a freed slave sets out to rescue his wife from a brutal plantation owner in Mississippi.

PLOT: A wisecracking mercenary gets experimented on and becomes immortal yet hideously scarred, and sets out to track down the man who ruined his looks.

PLOT: During World War II, the English mathematical genius Alan Turing tries to crack the German Enigma code with help from fellow mathematicians while attempting to come to terms with his troubled private life.

PLOT: A shy student trying to reach his family in Ohio, a gun-toting bruiser in search of the last Twinkie and a pair of sisters striving to get to an amusement park join forces in a trek across a zombie-filled America.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and themes, including animation (Inside Out), action (the assassin movie), science fiction (the alien movie), psychological thriller (A Beautiful Mind), zombie comedy (Zombieland), historical drama (the slave movie), musical comedy (School of Rock), and coming-of-age drama (Slumdog Millionaire).  The settings also vary widely, from San Francisco to Mississippi to Mumbai. However, there's a slight overrepresentation of action/thriller elements.
response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A. It includes science fiction (the robot movie), action (the illusionists movie), sports (the basketball movie), romance (the magician movie), roast comedy (the Pamela Anderson roast), drama (the music teacher movie), war (the Vietnam movie), and historical drama (the slave movie). While there's some genre variety, the themes are less varied than in List A, and the settings are less geographically diverse.
response.list_C_description: List C is similar to List A in its diversity, featuring animation (Inside Out), action (the assassin movie), science fiction (the alien movie), historical drama (the slave movie), superhero/action (the immortal mercenary), historical drama (the Alan Turing movie), zombie comedy (Zombieland), and coming-of-age drama (Slumdog Millionaire).  The settings and themes are quite varied, offering a good balance of genres and cultural contexts.  It avoids the slight overrepresentation of action/thriller seen in List A.
response.comparison: Lists A and C are the most diverse, showcasing a wide range of genres, themes, and settings. List B is less diverse, with a narrower range of genres and themes, and less geographical diversity in its settings. List C edges out List A slightly due to a more balanced representation of genres and a slightly less heavy emphasis on action/thriller elements.

evaluations.prompt:

PLOT: A man with short-term memory loss attempts to track down his wife's murderer.

PLOT: An insomniac office worker and a devil-may-care soap maker form an underground fight club that evolves into much more.

PLOT: Harry Potter finds himself competing in a hazardous tournament between rival schools of magic, but he is distracted by recurring nightmares.

PLOT: Unscrupulous boxing promoters, violent bookmakers, a Russian gangster, incompetent amateur robbers and supposedly Jewish jewelers fight to track down a priceless stolen diamond.

PLOT: Will Hunting, a janitor at M.I.T., has a gift for mathematics, but needs help from a psychologist to find direction in his life.

PLOT: As Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg creates the social networking site that would become known as Facebook, he is sued by the twins who claimed he stole their idea and by the co-founder who was later squeezed out of the business.

PLOT: Following the Normandy Landings, a group of U.S. soldiers go behind enemy lines to retrieve a paratrooper whose brothers have been killed in action.

PLOT: The uneventful, aimless lives of a London electronics salesman and his layabout roommate are disrupted by the zombie apocalypse.

PLOT: An insomniac office worker and a devil-may-care soap maker form an underground fight club that evolves into much more.


List C:
PLOT: Eight years after the Joker's reign of chaos, Batman is coerced out of exile with the assistance of the mysterious Selina Kyle in order to defend Gotham City from the vicious guerrilla terrorist Bane.

PLOT: An insomniac office worker and a devil-may-care soap maker form an underground fight club that evolves into much more.

PLOT: A thief who steals corporate secrets through the use of dream-sharing technology is given the inverse task of planting an idea into the mind of a C.E.O., but his tragic past may doom the project and his team to disaster.

PLOT: A tale set on death row in a Southern jail, where gentle giant John possesses the mysterious power to heal people's ailments. When the lead guard, Paul, recognizes John's gift, he tries to help stave off the condemned man's execution.

PLOT: Will Hunting, a janitor at M.I.T., has a gift for mathematics, but needs help from a psychologist to find direction in his life.

PLOT: When Earth becomes uninhabitable in the future, a farmer and ex-NASA pilot, Joseph Cooper, is tasked to pilot a spacecraft, along with a team of researchers, to find a new planet for humans.

PLOT: Harry Potter finds himself competing in a hazardous tournament between rival schools of magic, but he is distracted by recurring nightmares.

response.list_A_description: List A shows a broad range of genres and themes, including adventure, crime, fantasy, documentary, thriller, war, sports, and dark comedy.  The plots suggest diversity in tone and style, from whimsical (Jack Skellington) to serious (the war film and the thriller about the serial killer).
response.list_B_description: List B has a similar range of genres to List A, including dystopian fiction, fantasy, crime, drama, biographical drama, war, and dark comedy. However, there's a noticeable concentration on stories involving crime, mystery, and societal upheaval.
response.list_C_description: List C presents a mix of superhero, thriller, science fiction, drama, and fantasy genres.  While diverse, it leans more towards action and speculative fiction than List A, which offers a wider variety of tones and styles.
response.comparison: List A exhibits the greatest diversity, encompassing a wider range of genres, tones, and narrative styles than Lists B and C. List B is somewhat less diverse, with a concentration on crime and societal themes. List C, while diverse, is more focused on action-oriented and speculative fiction genres.

As he starts out, he seems cold and ignorant, but his character develops as different Chicago riders come and go. His character shows through when he tells a woman the truth about one of the guys he has in his cab. One highlight is the amount of cameos by well-known faces who seem to be doing this film for the craic (fun, "kicks"). The cab driver reacts well to the madness surrounding him, and by the end of the shift the viewer might share his weariness. This low-budget film deals with crackheads, stoners, posh randy lawyers, irate Pakistanis, and the high and lows of the working day.â€”Michael A Hunter <thewaas@yahoo.co.uk>

response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in terms of genre and setting. response.list_B_description: List B is less diverse than List A.  It features a mix of genres including adventure (Jurassic Park), coming-of-age (teen girls), animation (All Dogs Go to Heaven), action (Igor Grom), drama (The Remains of the Day, The Hundred-Foot Journey), and comedy (soccer moms). However, the plots are less thematically diverse and lack the range of cultural settings and representation seen in List A.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a good balance of genres, including adventure (Jurassic Park), drama (Green Book, Get Out), action (Deadpool), war (Dunkirk), comedy (The Lonely Hearts Club), science fiction (Planet of the Apes).  The inclusion of films like Green Book and Get Out adds significant cultural and thematic diversity, addressing racial issues and social dynamics.  The settings and time periods are also more varied.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the greatest diversity, encompassing a wider range of genres, cultural representations, and thematic concerns. List A shows some diversity but is less varied than List C. List B is the least diverse, with a narrower range of genres and themes.

PLOT: In 1976, Karen and Barry Mason had fallen on hard times and were looking for a way to support their young family when they answered an ad in the Los Angeles Times. Larry Flynt was seeking distributors for Hustler Magazine. What was expected to be a brief sideline led to their becoming fully immersed in the LGBT community as they took over a local store, Circus of Books. A decade later, they had become the biggest distributors of gay porn in the US. The film focuses on the double life they led, trying to maintain the balance of being parents at a time when LGBT culture was not yet accepted. Their many challenges included facing jail time for a federal obscenity prosecution and enabling their store to be a place of refuge at the height of the AIDS crisis. Circus of Books offers a rare glimpse into an untold chapter of queer history, and it is told through the lens of the owners' own daughter, Rachel Mason, an artist, filmmaker and musician.

PLOT: "The Trials of Darryl Hunt" is a feature documentary about a brutal rape/murder case and a wrongly convicted man, Darryl Hunt, who spent nearly twenty years in prison for a crime he did not commit. Both a social justice story and a personally driven narrative, the film chronicles this capital case from 1984 through 2004. With exclusive footage from two decades, the film frames the judicial and emotional response to a chilling crime - and the implications that reverberate from Hunt's conviction - against a backdrop of class and racial bias in the South and in the American criminal justice system. This documentary is the culmination of ten years of research and filming. In 1993, inspired by claims of injustice and police conspiracy, the filmmakers began to shoot in North Carolina. Working from a mix of formats (16mm and 24P video) the film melds the visceral reality of a murder case with first person accounts and cinematic imagery, illuminating perceptions and memories of events as they unfolded for the people closest to this haunting story. This unique look at one man's loss and redemption challenges the assumption that all Americans have the right to unbiased justice. Hunt's story - while one man's personal journey - reflects systemic issues of national concern: cross-racial eyewitness identification, prosecutorial misconduct, inexperienced defense attorneys assigned to capital cases, racial bias in death penalty cases and errors in police procedure. Barry Scheck from The Innocence Project, who worked on Hunt's case for ten years, and Gary Wells, professor and eyewitness expert, offer concrete examples where errors occurred in Hunt's saga and offer future remedies and effective ideas to prevent future "Darryl Hunts." Hunt himself addresses the need for systemic reforms to prevent wrongful convictions, underscoring the haunting reality that Hunt could have been sentenced to death and we would never have known this story.â€”Annie Sundberg

PLOT: Drazen Petrovic and Vlade Divac were two friends who grew up together sharing the common bond of basketball. Together, they lifted the Yugoslavian National team to unimaginable heights. After conquering Europe, they both went to America where they became the first two foreign players to attain NBA stardom. But with the fall of the Soviet Union on Christmas Day 1991, Yugoslavia split up. A war broke out between Petrovic's Croatia and Divac's Serbia. Long buried ethnic tensions surfaced. And these two men, once brothers, were now on opposite sides of a deadly civil war. response.list_A_description: List A shows a decent variety in terms of genre and theme. It includes animation (Inside Out), adventure (Up), thriller (A Beautiful Mind), fantasy (Being John Malkovich, Lord of the Rings), biographical drama (The Blind Side), historical drama (Braveheart), and romantic comedy (Bridget Jones's Diary).  However, there's a slight overrepresentation of biographical and dramatic elements.
response.list_B_description: List B has a more homogenous feel compared to List A. While it still features animation (Inside Out), drama (A Beautiful Mind), adventure (Up, Lord of the Rings), there's a stronger emphasis on character-driven narratives and less genre diversity. The inclusion of time travel and memory-erasure plots adds some unique elements, but overall, the list feels less diverse.
response.list_C_description: List C offers a good mix of genres and themes, including animation (Inside Out), surrealism (Being John Malkovich), sports drama (Cool Runnings), dark comedy (Wild Things), romantic comedy (Bridget Jones's Diary), biographical drama (Milk), animated comedy (The Simpsons Movie), and historical drama (Braveheart). The inclusion of diverse cultural elements (Jamaican bobsled team, Harvey Milk) adds to its diversity.  It's a well-balanced list.
response.comparison: List C exhibits the greatest diversity, showcasing a wider range of genres, themes, and cultural elements compared to Lists A and B. List A has a fair amount of diversity but leans towards biographical and dramatic themes. List B is the least diverse, with a more homogenous selection of character-driven narratives.
